instruction:
The background knowledge is:
The three-dimensional band structure and superconducting gap of Ba\({}_{0.6}\)K\({}_{0.4}\)Fe\({}_{2}\)As\({}_{2}\) are studied with angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy.

In contrast with previous results, we have identified three holelike Fermi surface sheets near the zone center with sizable out-of-plane or \(k_{z}\) dispersion.

The superconducting gap on certain Fermi surface sheets shows significant \(k_{z}\) dependence.Moreover, the superconducting gap sizes are different at the same Fermi momentum for two bands with different spatial symmetries (one odd, one even).

Our results further reveal the three-dimensional and orbital-dependent structure of the superconducting gap in iron pnictides, which facilitates the understanding of momentum-integrated measurements and provides a distinct test for theories.

text:
The three-dimensional band structure and superconducting gap of Ba\({}_{0.6}\)K\({}_{0.4}\)Fe\({}_{2}\)As\({}_{2}\) are studied with angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy.

In contrast with previous results, we have identified three holelike Fermi surface sheets near the zone center with sizable out-of-plane or \(k_{z}\) dispersion.

The superconducting gap on certain Fermi surface sheets shows significant \(k_{z}\) dependence.Moreover, the superconducting gap sizes are different at the same Fermi momentum for two bands with different spatial symmetries (one odd, one even).

Our results further reveal the three-dimensional and orbital-dependent structure of the superconducting gap in iron pnictides, which facilitates the understanding of momentum-integrated measurements and provides a distinct test for theories.

instruction:
The background knowledge is:
However, there is conflicting experimental evidence for the presence of nodes and nodeless superconducting gaps .

Furthermore, strongly anisotropic and multiple gap behavior has been deduced based on transport measurements .

One possible cause of these controversies is the multiband nature of iron-based superconductors that all the five Fe 3\(d\) orbitals participate in the low-lying electronic structure, giving hole pockets at the zone center and electron pockets at the zone corner .The importance of Fermi surface topology and its orbital character has been pointed out by recent theories .

It is proposed that the presence of a node is determined by the number of bands which cross the Fermi level and that there is a strong anisotropy and amplitude variation of the superconducting gaps on different Fermi surface sheets.

Moreover, various physical properties of iron-based superconductors are more three dimensional (3D) than the cuprates.For example, the isotropy of the upper critical field has been found in Ba\({}_{1-x}\)K\({}_{x}\)Fe\({}_{2}\)As\({}_{2}\).

Previous angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) studies have shown isotropic nodeless gaps on all the Fermi surface sheets in Ba\({}_{1-x}\)K\({}_{x}\)Fe\({}_{2}\)As\({}_{2}\), BaFe\({}_{2-y}\)Co\({}_{y}\)As\({}_{2}\), and Fe\({}_{1.03}\)Te\({}_{0.7}\)Se\({}_{0.3}\).The most representative and detailed data to date were taken on the optimally doped Ba\({}_{1-x}\)K\({}_{x}\)Fe\({}_{2}\)As\({}_{2}\) samples , where two hole pockets near the zone center were observed.

The superconducting gap on the inner hole pocket is found to be larger than that on the outer pocket, which is consistent with the \(s_{\pm}\) pairing symmetry with a gap function proportional to \(|\cos\k_{x}\cos\k_{y}|\).

However, there are still many issues to be resolved.For example, calculations predicted three hole bands at the zone center rather than two .

The relationship between orbital characters and superconducting gaps is yet to be established.

Furthermore, band calculation suggested that the 3D character of the electronic structure is important for the magnetism and superconductivity in iron-based superconductors .However, due to the limited photon energies used in previous ARPES studies, the superconducting gaps along the out-of-plane momentum (\(k_{z}\)) direction have not been exposed.

In this Letter, we have studied the \(k_{z}\) dependence of the superconducting gap in high-quality Ba\({}_{0.6}\)K\({}_{0.4}\)Fe\({}_{2}\)As\({}_{2}\) single crystals with ARPES.

We found that the Fermi surface near the zone center \(\Gamma\) actually contains three hole pockets instead of two as in previous studies.Significant \(k_{z}\) dependence of the superconducting gap is discovered on one of the bands.

Particularly, we found that at the same momentum, bands with different orbital symmetries could exhibit very different gap sizes.

Our results provide a more global picture of the gap, which would help the construction of microscopic models of the iron-based superconductors.High-quality Ba\({}_{0.6}\)K\({}_{0.4}\)Fe\({}_{2}\)As\({}_{2}\) (\(T_{c}\) = 38 K) single crystals were synthesized by the self-flux method with a superconducting transition width of 0.5 K. Data were taken with various photon energies at beam line 5-4 of the Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory (SSRL), and with the 21.2 eV helium-\(I\alpha\) line of a discharge lamp in mixed polarization geometry.Polarization-dependent data were taken at beam line 1 of the Hiroshima synchrotron radiation center (HSRC).

Two polarization geometries (\(E_{p}\), \(E_{s}\)) were achieved by rotating the experimental chamber.

All the data were taken with Scienta electron analyzers; the overall energy resolution is 15 meV at HSRC or 7 meV at SSRL, and angular resolution is 0.3\({}^{\circ}\).

The samples were cleaved _in situ_, and measured under ultra-high vacuum of \(5\times 10^{-11}\) Torr.

text:
However, there is conflicting experimental evidence for the presence of nodes and nodeless superconducting gaps .

Furthermore, strongly anisotropic and multiple gap behavior has been deduced based on transport measurements .

One possible cause of these controversies is the multiband nature of iron-based superconductors that all the five Fe 3\(d\) orbitals participate in the low-lying electronic structure, giving hole pockets at the zone center and electron pockets at the zone corner .The importance of Fermi surface topology and its orbital character has been pointed out by recent theories .

It is proposed that the presence of a node is determined by the number of bands which cross the Fermi level and that there is a strong anisotropy and amplitude variation of the superconducting gaps on different Fermi surface sheets.

Moreover, various physical properties of iron-based superconductors are more three dimensional (3D) than the cuprates.For example, the isotropy of the upper critical field has been found in Ba\({}_{1-x}\)K\({}_{x}\)Fe\({}_{2}\)As\({}_{2}\).

Previous angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) studies have shown isotropic nodeless gaps on all the Fermi surface sheets in Ba\({}_{1-x}\)K\({}_{x}\)Fe\({}_{2}\)As\({}_{2}\), BaFe\({}_{2-y}\)Co\({}_{y}\)As\({}_{2}\), and Fe\({}_{1.03}\)Te\({}_{0.7}\)Se\({}_{0.3}\).The most representative and detailed data to date were taken on the optimally doped Ba\({}_{1-x}\)K\({}_{x}\)Fe\({}_{2}\)As\({}_{2}\) samples , where two hole pockets near the zone center were observed.

The superconducting gap on the inner hole pocket is found to be larger than that on the outer pocket, which is consistent with the \(s_{\pm}\) pairing symmetry with a gap function proportional to \(|\cos\k_{x}\cos\k_{y}|\).

However, there are still many issues to be resolved.For example, calculations predicted three hole bands at the zone center rather than two .

The relationship between orbital characters and superconducting gaps is yet to be established.

Furthermore, band calculation suggested that the 3D character of the electronic structure is important for the magnetism and superconductivity in iron-based superconductors .However, due to the limited photon energies used in previous ARPES studies, the superconducting gaps along the out-of-plane momentum (\(k_{z}\)) direction have not been exposed.

In this Letter, we have studied the \(k_{z}\) dependence of the superconducting gap in high-quality Ba\({}_{0.6}\)K\({}_{0.4}\)Fe\({}_{2}\)As\({}_{2}\) single crystals with ARPES.

We found that the Fermi surface near the zone center \(\Gamma\) actually contains three hole pockets instead of two as in previous studies.Significant \(k_{z}\) dependence of the superconducting gap is discovered on one of the bands.

Particularly, we found that at the same momentum, bands with different orbital symmetries could exhibit very different gap sizes.

Our results provide a more global picture of the gap, which would help the construction of microscopic models of the iron-based superconductors.High-quality Ba\({}_{0.6}\)K\({}_{0.4}\)Fe\({}_{2}\)As\({}_{2}\) (\(T_{c}\) = 38 K) single crystals were synthesized by the self-flux method with a superconducting transition width of 0.5 K. Data were taken with various photon energies at beam line 5-4 of the Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory (SSRL), and with the 21.2 eV helium-\(I\alpha\) line of a discharge lamp in mixed polarization geometry.Polarization-dependent data were taken at beam line 1 of the Hiroshima synchrotron radiation center (HSRC).

Two polarization geometries (\(E_{p}\), \(E_{s}\)) were achieved by rotating the experimental chamber.

All the data were taken with Scienta electron analyzers; the overall energy resolution is 15 meV at HSRC or 7 meV at SSRL, and angular resolution is 0.3\({}^{\circ}\).

The samples were cleaved _in situ_, and measured under ultra-high vacuum of \(5\times 10^{-11}\) Torr.

Here are some instructions questions generated from the text:

1. What is the main controversy regarding the existence of nodes and nodeless superconducting gaps in iron-based superconductors?
2. How does the multiband nature of iron-based superconductors affect their electrical properties compared to cuprates?
3. According to theory, what determines whether a material exhibits nodal or non-nodal superconductivity?
4. Which crystal system, Ba\(_{1-x}\)K\(_{x}\)Fe\(_{2}\)As\(_{2}\), was previously found to display isotropic nodeless gaps on all Fermi surface sheets?
5. Why did previous ARPES studies only reveal isotropic gap structures on certain Fermi surfaces?
6. Can you describe the difference in size of superconducting gaps on the inner and outer hole pockets observed in Ba\(_{1-x}\)K\(_{x}\)Fe\(_{2}\)As\(_{2}\)?
7. In Ba\(_{1-x}\)K\(_{x}\)Fe\(_{2}\)As\(_{2}\), how did the calculated band structure compare to predictions, specifically regarding hole band numbers at the zone center?
8. What remains unclear regarding the role of orbital characters in determining superconducting gaps in iron-based superconductors?
9. Does a comparison of ARPES data across different materials suggest significant differences in electronic structure between iron-based superconductors and cuprates?
10. What new information did the authors' research hope to provide regarding the microphysical origin of iron-based superconductors? 
11. What specific issue(s) remain unsolved despite previous attempts to understand iron-based superconductors through ARPES experiments?
12. Could you explain why it's crucial to investigate the k\(_{z}\)-dependence of superconducting gaps in iron-based superconductors?
13. Based on the study findings, how might understanding the relationships between orbital symmetries and gap sizes aid in constructing more accurate models of iron-based superconductors?
14. Were any special sample preparation techniques required before conducting ARPES experiments, and if so, why?
15. Are there potential implications for our understanding of 3-dimensional vs. 2-dimensional electronics in light of the distinct characteristics displayed by iron-based superconductors?

instruction:
The background knowledge is:
Since the superconducting gap is almost isotropic around the Fermi surface cross section of certain \(k_{z}\), we focus on the (0, 0)-(\(\pi\), \(\pi\)) high symmetry cut for simplicity.

The photon energy dependent data are shown in Fig.

1.

Only two bands could be resolved in 25 eV [Fig.

1(a)], forming two hole pockets as reported in previous studies.

However, by changing the photon energy, we could observe an additional band (\(\beta\)) moving outwards in 29.5 and 31 eV [Figs.

1(b) and 1(c)].1(b) and 1(c)].

The Fermi momenta (\(k_{F}\)) of these three bands are determined by peak positions in momentum distribution curves (MDCs) at the Fermi energy (\(E_{F}\)) in Fig.

1(d).

Taking the inner potential of 15 eV to calculate the \(k_{z}\)'s of different photon energies, our data cover half of the Brillouin zone along the \(k_{z}\) direction from \(\Gamma\) with \(\sim\)21 eV photons to \(Z\) with \(\sim\)31 eV photons [Fig.

1(e)].1(e)].

While \(\alpha\) and \(\gamma\) show little \(k_{z}\) dispersion, \(\beta\) is almost degenerate with \(\alpha\) near \(\Gamma\), but moves outward significantly near \(Z\).

Since the photon energies applied in most previous ARPES studies could just sample the \(\Gamma\) region, \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) could not be distinguished .Therefore, three hole pockets reported here with distinct \(k_{z}\) dispersions naturally resolve the previous inconsistency with band calculations , which predicted three hole pockets around the zone center.

To further reveal the orbital characters of these three bands, we have conducted polarization-dependent ARPES experiments.The polarization geometry \(E_{p}(E_{s})\) could be achieved with the polarization direction parallel (perpendicular) to the mirror plane defined by the sample normal and the \((0,0)\)-(\(\pi\), \(\pi\)) direction.

The orbitals of even (odd) symmetry with respect to the mirror plane could be observed in \(E_{p}(E_{s})\) geometry .

The polarization-dependent data around \(Z\) are shown in Figs.

2(a)-2(d).

\(\beta\) could be observed in \(E_{p}\) geometry; thus, it is of an even orbital character.Oppositely, \(\alpha\) only shows up in the \(E_{s}\) geometry, which suggests an odd orbital character.

\(\gamma\) is mostly of odd orbital character [Figs.

2(c) and 2(d)], but there is also some trace of \(\gamma\) in \(E_{p}\) geometry due to possible orbital mixing.

The MDCs at \(E_{F}\) of different polarization geometries around \(Z\) are compared in Fig.

2(e).

The peak positions in \(E_{p}\) and \(E_{s}\) geometry are consistent with the data taken in mixed polarization geometry.Since the different orbital symmetries of \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) should not change along the \(k_{z}\) direction , it enables us to separate them with polarization-dependent experiment around \(\Gamma\).

The MDC peaks of \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) show up at the same momentum in Fig.

2(j).

This further proves that the \(k_{F}\)'s of the \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) bands almost degenerate around \(\Gamma\), but separate from each Figure 1 (color online).(a)–(c) Photoemission data of Ba\({}_{0.6}\)K\({}_{0.44}\)Fe\({}_{2}\)As\({}_{2}\) along the \((0,0)\)-(\(\pi,\pi\)) direction taken with 25, 29.5, and 31 eV, respectively.

(d) The MDCs at \(E_{F}\) taken with different photon energies are stacked.

The inset shows the projection of the cuts in the 2D Brillouin zone.

(e) The \(k_{F}\)’s determined from the MDCs in (d).

Data were taken at 10 K. Figure 2 (color online).Data were taken at 10 K. Figure 2 (color online).

(a) Photoemission intensity near \(Z\) along the \((0,0)\)-(\(\pi,\pi\)) direction taken in the \(E_{p}\) geometry with 31 eV photons.

(b) The second derivative with respect to energy of data in (a).

Panels (c) and (d) are the same as (a) and (b), respectively, but taken in the \(E_{s}\) geometry.

(e) The MDCs at \(E_{F}\) with mixed, \(E_{p}\), and \(E_{s}\) polarization geometries near \(Z\).

(b) The second derivative with respect to energy of data in (a).

Here are some instruction questions generated:

1. What type of material was studied using angle-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy (ARPES)?
2. According to the text, what is the primary reason why only two bands were previously observed in ARPES spectra?
3. At what photon energies did researchers observe a third band (β) besides α and γ, and how did they confirm its presence?
4. How does the orbital character of β differ from those of α and γ according to polarization-dependent ARPES results?
5. In analyzing the Fermi momenta of α and β along kz, what conclusion was drawn regarding their behavior around Γ and Z points?
6. What is the purpose of determining the polarization dependence of the spectral weight of Fermiology-related quantities like α and β?
7. Specifically, what physical phenomenon causes bandwidths and effective masses of electrons to become anisotropic in the Brillouin zone?
8. Can you identify any inconsistencies between experimentally found feature sets and existing theory-based models described earlier in this study? If yes, explain how these findings address the discrepancies.
9. Describe briefly the procedure followed to analyze the Fermionic data against quantum field theories under consideration for comparison purposes? Be precise in addressing all facets related thereto.

Here are some instructional questions based on the provided text:

1. What phenomenon occurs in the superconducting gap around the Fermi surface cross-section of certain k_z values?

2. How many bands were initially visible in the photoemission spectrum taken with a 25-eV photon energy, and what shape did they form?

3. In which energy ranges were the additional bands alpha and beta first detected?

4. How does the orbital symmetry depend on the polarization direction in ARPE spectroscopy experiments?

5. According to the given data, what is the trend of the dispersion of band beta in terms of kz coordinates?

6. Why was it difficult to distinguish between bands α and β in earlier ARPES studies using standard photon energies?

7. Based on the research presented, how does the discovery of the third hole pocket contribute to resolving inconsistencies between experimental results and theoretical predictions regarding the number of hole pockets in the studied material?

8. What kind of orbits exhibit symmetric properties relative to the mirror plane formed by the sample's normal vector and the (0,0)-(π,π) direction?

9. What conclusions may be drawn about the orbital characters of the various spectral features near Z by analyzing their presence or absence in E_p and Es measurements?

10. Can one confirm that bands α and β maintain the same Fermi wave numbers (kf_s) over a range of kz values merely through examination of the MDC spectra?

instruction:
The background knowledge is:
Panels (f)–(i) are the same as (a)–(d), respectively, but taken with 45 eV photons to reach the \(\Gamma\) point.

(j) The MDCs at \(E_{F}\) with mixed, \(E_{p}\), and \(E_{s}\) polarization geometries near \(\Gamma\).

Data were taken at 40 K. other around \(Z\).

Note that the intensity of \(\gamma\) is very weak in the data taken with 45 eV photons, possibly due to the matrix element effects of this particular photon energy.The two odd and one even bands observed here qualitatively agree with the band calculations, where only three orbitals (\(d_{xz}\), \(d_{yz}\), and \(d_{xy}\)) contribute to the low energy electronic structure around \(\Gamma\).

\(\beta\) is \(d_{xz}\) orbital due to its even symmetry.

\(\gamma\) shows little \(k_{z}\) dispersion, which is most likely the \(d_{xy}\) orbital with two-dimensional (2D) character.\(\alpha\) is thus assigned to the \(d_{yz}\) orbital, which is predicted to degenerate with the \(d_{xz}\) orbital at \(\Gamma\) by theory.

Note that there are some broad spectral weights (\(\sigma\)) at \((0,0)\), which is possibly due to the contribution of \(d_{z^{2}}\) bands below \(E_{F}\) or the incoherent spectral weight scattered from other states [Figs.

1 and 2(a)]; they are thus ignored in the following discussions.

The data in the superconducting state near \(\Gamma\) are shown in Figs.3(a) and 3(b).

The \(\gamma\) band shows simple Bogoliubov dispersion with a gap about 4 meV.

Most notably, at the \(k_{F}\)'s of the \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) bands, the energy distribution curves (EDCs) exhibit a complex structure with two peaks [Figs.

3(g) and 3(h)].

The peak positions could be tracked towards \(\Gamma\) with Bogoliubov dispersion of two energy scales (7 and 11.5 meV) as shown in Fig.

3(e).

The energy scale of 11.5 meV is consistent with the gap size observed in previous studies .Moreover, the clear bending-over behavior and small peak width clearly reproduce the properties of a superconducting peak.

Furthermore, the peak at 7 meV should not be the bent-over feature of \(\gamma\), as one can track the \(\gamma\) band by the triangles in Figs.

3(g) and 3(h).

It quickly bends over to high binding energies and loses its weight significantly.Therefore, the most natural explanation of our results is that \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) have different superconducting gaps at the same momentum.

On the other hand, while these three bands could be clearly separated around \(Z\) in Fig.

3(c), only single peaks could be observed at the \(k_{F}\)'s of \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) with a superconducting gap of 7 meV [Fig.

3(i)].3(i)].

In the five-band model, the Fermi surface sheets of iron-based superconductors consist of sections with different orbital characters .

The multiorbital interactions could form strong gap anisotropy on the Fermi surface sheets.

Therefore, the observation of two energy scales of \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) could be related to their orbital nature, since they show opposite orbital symmetries at the same Fermi momentum.That is, the pairing strengths could be strongly determined by the orbital symmetries.

The next question is which band provides a larger gap around \(\Gamma\).

Considering there is a significant change from 11.5 to 7 meV for one of the gaps along the \(k_{z}\) direction, plus the strong \(k_{z}\) dependence of \(\beta\), it is reasonable to assume that \(\beta\) contributes to the larger gap of 11.5 meV around \(\Gamma\).We could not completely exclude the possibility of \(\alpha\) at this stage, but this assumption would only affect the gap assignment around \(\Gamma\), and would not affect the observed \(k_{z}\) dependence of the superconducting gaps discussed below.

Polarization-dependent experiments with high resolution in the superconducting state are needed to clarify this point.

We leave this for future studies.

text:
Panels (f)–(i) are the same as (a)–(d), respectively, but taken with 45 eV photons to reach the \(\Gamma\) point.

(j) The MDCs at \(E_{F}\) with mixed, \(E_{p}\), and \(E_{s}\) polarization geometries near \(\Gamma\).

Data were taken at 40 K. other around \(Z\).

Note that the intensity of \(\gamma\) is very weak in the data taken with 45 eV photons, possibly due to the matrix element effects of this particular photon energy.The two odd and one even bands observed here qualitatively agree with the band calculations, where only three orbitals (\(d_{xz}\), \(d_{yz}\), and \(d_{xy}\)) contribute to the low energy electronic structure around \(\Gamma\).

\(\beta\) is \(d_{xz}\) orbital due to its even symmetry.

\(\gamma\) shows little \(k_{z}\) dispersion, which is most likely the \(d_{xy}\) orbital with two-dimensional (2D) character.\(\alpha\) is thus assigned to the \(d_{yz}\) orbital, which is predicted to degenerate with the \(d_{xz}\) orbital at \(\Gamma\) by theory.

Note that there are some broad spectral weights (\(\sigma\)) at \((0,0)\), which is possibly due to the contribution of \(d_{z^{2}}\) bands below \(E_{F}\) or the incoherent spectral weight scattered from other states [Figs.

1 and 2(a)]; they are thus ignored in the following discussions.

The data in the superconducting state near \(\Gamma\) are shown in Figs.3(a) and 3(b).

The \(\gamma\) band shows simple Bogoliubov dispersion with a gap about 4 meV.

Most notably, at the \(k_{F}\)'s of the \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) bands, the energy distribution curves (EDCs) exhibit a complex structure with two peaks [Figs.

3(g) and 3(h)].

The peak positions could be tracked towards \(\Gamma\) with Bogoliubov dispersion of two energy scales (7 and 11.5 meV) as shown in Fig.

3(e).

The energy scale of 11.5 meV is consistent with the gap size observed in previous studies .Moreover, the clear bending-over behavior and small peak width clearly reproduce the properties of a superconducting peak.

Furthermore, the peak at 7 meV should not be the bent-over feature of \(\gamma\), as one can track the \(\gamma\) band by the triangles in Figs.

3(g) and 3(h).

It quickly bends over to high binding energies and loses its weight significantly.Therefore, the most natural explanation of our results is that \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) have different superconducting gaps at the same momentum.

On the other hand, while these three bands could be clearly separated around \(Z\) in Fig.

3(c), only single peaks could be observed at the \(k_{F}\)'s of \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) with a superconducting gap of 7 meV [Fig.

3(i)].3(i)].

In the five-band model, the Fermi surface sheets of iron-based superconductors consist of sections with different orbital characters .

The multiorbital interactions could form strong gap anisotropy on the Fermi surface sheets.

Therefore, the observation of two energy scales of \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) could be related to their orbital nature, since they show opposite orbital symmetries at the same Fermi momentum.That is, the pairing strengths could be strongly determined by the orbital symmetries.

The next question is which band provides a larger gap around \(\Gamma\).

Considering there is a significant change from 11.5 to 7 meV for one of the gaps along the \(k_{z}\) direction, plus the strong \(k_{z}\) dependence of \(\beta\), it is reasonable to assume that \(\beta\) contributes to the larger gap of 11.5 meV around \(\Gamma\).We could not completely exclude the possibility of \(\alpha\) at this stage, but this assumption would only affect the gap assignment around \(\Gamma\), and would not affect the observed \(k_{z}\) dependence of the superconducting gaps discussed below.

Polarization-dependent experiments with high resolution in the superconducting state are needed to clarify this point.

We leave this for future studies.

instruction:
The background knowledge is:
We leave this for future studies.

The symmetrized EDCs at the \(k_{F}\)'s of the \(\alpha\), \(\beta\), and \(\gamma\) bands are summarized in Figs.

4(a)-4(c).

The two-peak behavior could only be resolved around \(\Gamma\).

The superconducting gap values are determined by fitting with the common phenomenological superconducting spectral function as illustrated in Fig.

4(a) .

The \(k_{z}\) dependence of superconducting gaps is shown in Fig.

4(e).4(e).

The gap sizes of \(\alpha\) and \(\gamma\) are about 7 and 4 meV, respectively, and the gap sizes of \(\beta\) show strong \(k_{z}\) dependence from 11.5 to 7 meV.

In previous ARPES studies, the gap sizes around \(\Gamma\) could be fitted with \(\Delta_{0}[\cos k_{x}\cos k_{y}]\).

Therefore, the superconducting gap should decrease away from the \((0,0)\) point.

We plot the superconducting gap versus \(|\cos k_{x}\cos k_{y}|\) in Fig.

4(g).4(g).

The \(\alpha\) and \(\gamma\) bands could be well fitted in this relation with \(\Delta_{0}\approx 8\) meV, as shown by the straight line in Fig.

4(g).

However, the large deviation of the \(\beta\) band (highlighted by the shaded region) indicates that the \(k_{z}\) dependence of the gap sizes of \(\beta\) could not be explained by the change of in-plane Fermi surface size.

Therefore, the \(k_{z}\) contribution must be included to describe the gap function of the \(\beta\) band.With the simple formula of \(\Delta_{0\beta}|\cos k_{x}\cos k_{y}|(1+A\cos k_{z})\), one can fit the gap of \(\beta\) reasonably well with \(\Delta_{0\beta}\approx 11.2\) meV and \(A\approx 0.24\) as shown by the solid line in Fig.

4(e).

Figure 3 (color online).

(a),(b) Photoemission intensities taken with 21.2 eV along two momentum cuts as indicated in (d).

(c) Same as (a), but taken near \(Z\) with 31 eV photon energy.

Panels (e) and (f) are illustrations of the bands in (a) and (c), respectively.(g)–(i) EDCs of the data in (a)–(c), respectively.

Data were taken at 10 K. The \(k_{z}\)-dependent superconducting gaps discovered here could not be explained in 2D models, which are used to construct the pairing mechanism in most of the previous theories .

In contrast to cuprates, the iron-based superconductors show many 3D characters, e.g., the small anisotropy of the upper critical field , and 3D spin fluctuations in parent and doped compounds .Our results further emphasize the 3D character of the superconductivity, where the out-of-plane pairing channels should be considered.

Consistently, a substantial \(k_{z}\) dependence of the superconducting order parameter has been found in a recent 3D band model that is constructed to calculate the spin fluctuations and the pairing function .

The superconducting gap size is proposed to be related to the nesting condition of Fermi surface sheets between \(\Gamma\) and \(M\) in previous ARPES studies .The Fermi surface sizes near the zone corner show weak \(k_{z}\) dependence .

In that case, the change of the Fermi surface size of \(\beta\) along the \(k_{z}\) direction could break the nesting condition, and thus significantly change the superconducting gaps.

However, it could not explain the different gap sizes of \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\), since they have almost the same Fermi surface size around \(\Gamma\).Moreover, the \(k_{z}\) dependence of gaps near the zone corner is not as obvious, as shown in Figs.

4(d) and 4(f), and the gap sizes also deviate from the fitting of the \(|\cos k_{x}\cos k_{y}|\) relation in Fig.

4(g).

Therefore, the pairing between \(\Gamma\) and \(M\) could not be related to just simple nesting of the Fermi surface.

The orbital character and the 3D electronic structure should be taken into account.

4(d) and 4(f), and the gap sizes also deviate from the fitting of the \(|\cos k_{x}\cos k_{y}|\) relation in Fig.

instruction:
The background knowledge is:
To summarize, the superconducting gap in Ba\({}_{0.6}\)K\({}_{0.4}\)Fe\({}_{2}\)As\({}_{2}\) shows strong out-of-plane and orbital symmetry dependence, which could be related to the 3D electronic structure and multiorbital nature of iron-based superconductors.

Our results have set up a more comprehensive picture of the superconducting gap in this compound.

We gratefully acknowledge the experimental support by Dr. D. H. Lu and Dr. R. G. Moore at at SSRL.
